items.title: We have a lot of exciting launches related to Codex coming over the next month, starting next week. ...
items.content:
We have a lot of exciting launches related to Codex coming over the next month, starting next week. We hope you will be delighted.

We are going to reach the Cybersecurity High level on our preparedness framework soon. We have been getting ready for this.

Cybersecurity is tricky and inherently dual-use; we believe the best thing for the world is for security issues to get patched quickly. We will start with product restrictions, like attempting to block people using our coding models to commit cybercrime (eg ‚Äòhack into this bank and steal the money‚Äô).

Long-term and as we can support it with evidence, we plan to move to defensive acceleration‚Äîhelping people patch bugs‚Äîas the primary mitigation.

It is very important the world adopts these tools quickly to make software more secure. There will be many very capable models in the world soon.
items.author: @sama
items.summary: Sam Altman announces upcoming Codex-related launches starting next week, reveals OpenAI will soon reach 'Cybersecurity High' level on their preparedness framework. Outlines approach: product restrictions initially (blocking cybercrime use), then 'defensive acceleration' to help patch bugs. Emphasizes urgency for world to adopt these tools.

items.title: One of the most common mistakes people make when evaluating the pace of AI research is to look at pr...
items.content:
One of the most common mistakes people make when evaluating the pace of AI research is to look at progress on one type of task and extrapolate it to all tasks that humans can do.

AI progress is extremely vertical-specific. In the past year, verifiable domains and in particular code have shown fast progress, which does not extend to other domains. This is because the main driver of AI capabilities remains, to this day, the memorization and operationalization of past data, which can be generated in unlimited quantity in the case of verifiable domains.

items.summary: Fran√ßois Chollet argues AI progress is 'extremely vertical-specific' - fast progress in verifiable domains like code doesn't extend to other domains. Main driver remains memorization/operationalization of past data, which can be generated unlimitedly only for verifiable domains.

items.title: How can businesses go beyond using AI for incremental efficiency gains to create transformative impa...
items.content:
How can businesses go beyond using AI for incremental efficiency gains to create transformative impact? I write from the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, where I‚Äôve been speaking with many CEOs about how to use AI for growth. A recurring theme is that running many experimental, bottom-up AI projects ‚Äî letting a thousand flowers bloom ‚Äî has failed to lead to significant payoffs. Instead, bigger gains require workflow redesign: taking a broader, perhaps top-down view of the multiple steps in a process and changing how they work together from end to end.

Consider a bank issuing loans. The workflow consists of several discrete stages: 

Marketing -> Application -> Preliminary Approval -> Final Review -> Execution

Suppose each step used to be manual. Preliminary Approval used to require an hour-long human review, but a new agentic system can do this automatically in 10 minutes. Swapping human review for AI review ‚Äî but keeping everything else the same ‚Äî gives a minor efficiency gain but isn‚Äôt transformative.

Here‚Äôs what would be transformative: Instead of applicants waiting a week for a human to review their application, they can get a decision in 10 minutes. When that happens, the loan becomes a more compelling product, and that better customer experience allows lenders to attract more applications and ultimately issue more loans.

However, making this change requires taking a broader business or product perspective, not just a technology perspective. Further, it changes the workflow of loan processing. Switching to offering a ‚Äú10-minute loan‚Äù product would require changing how it is marketed. Applications would need to be digitized and routed more efficiently, and final review and execution would need to be redesigned to handle a larger volume.

Even though AI is applied only to one step, Preliminary Approval, we end up implementing not just a point solution but a broader workflow redesign that transforms the product offering.

At AI Aspire (an advisory firm I co-lead), here‚Äôs what we see: Bottom-up innovation matters because the people closest to problems often see solutions first. But scaling such ideas to create transformative impact often requires seeing how AI can transform entire workflows end to end, not just individual steps, and this is where top-down strategic direction and innovation can help.

This year's WEF meeting, as in previous years, has been an energizing event. Among technologists, frequent topics of discussion include Agentic AI (when I coined this term, I was not expecting to see it plastered on billboards and buildings!), Sovereign AI (how nations can control their own access to AI), Talent (the challenging job market for recent graduates, and how to upskill nations), and data-center infrastructure (how to address bottlenecks in energy, talent, GPU chips, and memory). I will address some of these topics in future posts.

Against the backdrop of geopolitical uncertainty, I hope all of us in AI will keep building bridges that connect nations, sharing through open source, and¬†building to benefit all nations and all people.

[Original text: https://t.co/Ck52mNGX4a ]

items.content_html:
How much value is locked up here on X?

Or, what is the money doing in AI?

I had @blevlabs's AI (a state of the art cognitive architecture that works a lot better than Grok or ChatGPT for these kinds of agentic tasks) run me a report on my four investor lists (all VC firms, and all private investors).

I'm wondering if this is valuable to you? Like would you pay $250 a month to run daily reports like this? (Running the X API is expensive).

I give you this one for free, because it shows you just how much flows by in just a few hours, this is all after reading just a few thousand posts from past few hours.

See the entire thread for the full report, obviously it could be more readable, delivered in a PDF, and gotta check to make sure all the links are correct (like all AIs it does make mistakes here and there).

+++++++++++++

All AI done.

items.title:
It's an easiest time to make a master's or a PhD:

1. You pick a bunch of recent papers from scienti...
items.content:
It's an easiest time to make a master's or a PhD:

1. You pick a bunch of recent papers from scientists in your research domain, submit them to a chatbot, and ask it to analyze the "future works" sections and propose experiments to try.

2. You ask the chatbot to write code for these experiments.

3. You run this code and get some incremental results not published anywhere else.

4. You ask the chatbot to write a paper about these incremental results.

5. You submit this paper to a third-tier conference in your domain where the acceptance rate is above 0.5.

Three papers like that and you are ready to write a thesis.

I guess you already know how to get the thesis written fast.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Andriy Burkov outlines how AI makes academic degrees easier: use chatbot to analyze papers' future works, generate code for experiments, run for incremental results, write papers, submit to lower-tier conferences.
items.reasoning: Provocative observation about AI's impact on academic integrity. Very high engagement (111K views, 1K likes). Raises important questions about research quality.

items.title:
AI is automating software engineering by removing bottlenecks around writing code.

But imo it is te...
items.content:
AI is automating software engineering by removing bottlenecks around writing code.

But imo it is terrible at writing english. None of the 'good' writers are using AI to directly write blogs, essays, PRDs, emails, or any work-related document that conveys high-level intent or thought. I have an instinctive negative reflex anytime I see a hastily-AI generated essay full of LLM-isms and slop.

Because writing english (or any other language) is a higher-level abstraction, this seems like a strictly harder problem than writing code - where the goal is more to translate intent into an executable program.

There are of course 'lower-level tasks' involving english that don't require expressing complex thoughts - email scheduling, accounting, even doing certain types of legal work. And that is solvable today. But writing longer thought pieces, brainstorms, specs still sits within the realm of the human for now. 

If AI can more fully automate written communication at this layer, it'll unlock the broader category of knowledge work beyond coding and "lower-level knowledge work". It'll just be a tougher task to achieve.

items.summary: Jerry Liu argues AI automates coding but is terrible at writing English - good writers don't use AI for blogs/PRDs/essays. Suggests English writing is harder abstraction than code translation.

items.title:
A new kind of interactive TV coming? Dreaming about the future.

In the old days we used to use scre...
items.content:
A new kind of interactive TV coming? Dreaming about the future.

In the old days we used to use screen savers to save our screens. If you had an early plasma TV you‚Äôd need them to make sure your screen wouldn‚Äôt burn in. Now on my Apple TV I have the Snoopy screen saver running, in big part because I grew up with Snoopy showing up every day in the comic strips that came with our newspaper. Those days are long gone, haven‚Äôt read a newspaper in years, but Snoopy survives.

Been playing with https://t.co/JdEP14Wq5s and playing with this new real-time world model, which makes videos very differently than, say, Kling does. 

It is a next frame predictor, so you can change the scene and action by typing to it.

But in playing with it a lot lately I‚Äôve found it‚Äôs addictive to use, not because it‚Äôs highly accurate, but because it is interactive. Right now it‚Äôs a bit limited, will only play for a few minutes, partly, I hear, because generating video this way costs a lot per minute. 

There are a lot of researchers in AI working to make these kinds of real-time world models cheaper, and better, but I remember the days about two years ago when AI video generators first came on the market. Back then everything would look hallucinated with people who had multiple fingers. Today those kinds of models generate cinematic scenes that are even being used in Hollywood to create new scenes and camera moves.

In two years this new form will be a lot better, and they arrive in a world where autonomous vehicles will be coming out of the woodwork and new kinds of AI-driven glasses/headsets are going to come with a new form of virtual reality driven by these new models. 

Imagine sitting in a Waymo or a Tesla Robotaxi with your family where you are able to talk to the screen and have a whole bunch of different things happening in reaction.

‚ÄúTake us skiing in the Swiss Alps.‚Äù
‚ÄúShow an alien playing in Minecraft.‚Äù
‚ÄúShow fire breathing dragons destroying a city.‚Äù

Really anything your mind can come up with could be on the screen nearly instantly. 

Isn‚Äôt this a new form of a video game for the family? Yeah!

And it could get really crazy inside a new pair of glasses. 

Dreaming is the role of these today. Sometimes I just need to take a rest from reading X, which overloads my brain with heady posts about new things. I open up Pixverse and type in something and just am entertained by the visuals it shows me, lots of fun on the screen for my kids too. 

But doing that causes me to dream about a new Holodeck coming soon where we can talk and have anything happen.

When you try it, what do you dream about? A new video game? A new funny TV show? A new screen saver? Or just a mind break from working that‚Äôs different than going back to social media to read the news?

I dream of sending it a little prompt of a story and having it perform the story for me. While riding in an autonomous car with my kids. 

If I had the ear of the engineering team, I wish I could airplay it to my TV so we could sit around the TV asking for new visuals ‚Äúhey Pixverse put on the screen a bunch of sharks chasing someone on a jet ski.‚Äù 

I bet such a thing happens soon. Screen savers are about to become a lot more fun.

items.title:
10 new AI startups.

Jeremiah Owyang is keeping a tight ship at his Llama Lounge. 

The woman with a...
items.content:
10 new AI startups.

Jeremiah Owyang is keeping a tight ship at his Llama Lounge. 

The woman with an emotional AI gave me a ride to Millbrae where I picked up a Tesla Robotaxi home to San Jose. I forgot that my car would be locked up at 8 p.m. So left it in San Francisco, which gave me a chance to try Robotaxi again, my 14th ride in one.

I hit a bug. Put in the wrong address by accident. But when I figured out where we were I tried to order a new Robotaxi. Couldn't hire the one right in front of me. So had to wait 15 minutes for another to show up. 

Other than that it is like being in a Space Ship compared to my 2018 Tesla. The kinks are still being worked out. Hopefully will be fixed before it scales up starting soon. 

The safety monitor never touched the car on either ride. The AI is getting so good.

The Apple Vision Pro that I used to shoot this is blowing my mind. It's even more lifelike and the smoothness of the systems that steady this video are just so nice.

When I see this live it looks like reality.

Except it's not. I'm just watching two 5K chips in front of my eyes. 

But my brain thinks I'm viewing reality. 

It's such a mind bender every time I shoot in it.

I'm honored that Jeremiah lets me capture it. When I wear it in public it is weird, but it sure feels like the future.

items.summary_html: Scobleizer reports from Llama Lounge on 10 AI startups, Tesla Robotaxi experience (14th ride), Apple Vision Pro filming - describes robotaxi safety improvements and Vision Pro's lifelike quality
items.content_html:
10 new AI startups.

Jeremiah Owyang is keeping a tight ship at his Llama Lounge.

The woman with an emotional AI gave me a ride to Millbrae where I picked up a Tesla Robotaxi home to San Jose. I forgot that my car would be locked up at 8 p.m. So left it in San Francisco, which gave me a chance to try Robotaxi again, my 14th ride in one.

I hit a bug. Put in the wrong address by accident. But when I figured out where we were I tried to order a new Robotaxi. Couldn't hire the one right in front of me. So had to wait 15 minutes for another to show up.

Other than that it is like being in a Space Ship compared to my 2018 Tesla. The kinks are still being worked out. Hopefully will be fixed before it scales up starting soon.

The safety monitor never touched the car on either ride. The AI is getting so good.

The Apple Vision Pro that I used to shoot this is blowing my mind. It's even more lifelike and the smoothness of the systems that steady this video are just so nice.

When I see this live it looks like reality.

Except it's not. I'm just watching two 5K chips in front of my eyes.

But my brain thinks I'm viewing reality.

It's such a mind bender every time I shoot in it.

I'm honored that Jeremiah lets me capture it. When I wear it in public it is weird, but it sure feels like the future.

items.title:
Make Claude Cowork actually understand complex research reports üìäüìë

Claude Cowork is awesome, and it...
items.content:
Make Claude Cowork actually understand complex research reports üìäüìë

Claude Cowork is awesome, and it‚Äôs great at reading plaintext files, but it lacks the ability to accurately/efficiently analyze complex document formats, like PDF, Word, Pptx, etc. (more on this in a thread later; tl;dr it needs to write too much stuff from scratch).

I made a simple command that can export any complex document into high-quality markdown, courtesy of LlamaParse. In the video below, we parse all visuals in this CB Insights report into markdown-formatted text and tables.

This lets Claude Cowork do analysis over any document and give highly accurate responses in seconds.

My simple wrapper over semtools to batch export files into markdown: https://t.co/Et8IwvxHsY

Sign up to LlamaCloud: https://t.co/qsGFaIL7uM
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) demonstrates tool to make Claude Cowork understand complex documents (PDF, Word, PPTX) by exporting to markdown via LlamaParse

items.title:
Build agentic document workflows with @n8n_io + LlamaCloud

n8n is an awesome agent workflow engine....
items.content:
Build agentic document workflows with @n8n_io + LlamaCloud

n8n is an awesome agent workflow engine. However, for higher-accuracy document extraction tasks, the default doc extraction capabilities don't cut it.

We've built first-party support for LlamaCloud so you can use very high accuracy document parsing, extraction, classification, excel parsing, and even retrieval as part of your e2e n8n application - whether that's:
- a RAG chatbot over your files
- automating attachment processing over your emails 
- augmenting document analysis with extracted data from the web

or any other document agent use case! 

Come check it out: https://t.co/jHdUmUlNlO
Sign up to LlamaCloud: https://t.co/qsGFaIL7uM

items.title:
Most people think ‚ÄúAI in the real world‚Äù means another app.

I think that‚Äôs wrong.

This palm-sized ...
items.content:
Most people think ‚ÄúAI in the real world‚Äù means another app.

I think that‚Äôs wrong.

This palm-sized robot from @huggingface runs fully local, no cloud, no APIs, no black box, yet it listens, sees, learns, and responds in real time.

That shift changes everything.

Here‚Äôs why it matters ‚Üí
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Ronald van Loon discusses Hugging Face's palm-sized robot that runs fully local (no cloud/APIs), with real-time listening, vision, and response capabilities. Emphasizes shift from cloud-dependent to edge AI.
items.reasoning: Substantive thread on embodied AI and edge computing. Hugging Face robot is notable hardware development. Part of multi-post thread with practical workflow insights.
items.summary_html: Ronald van Loon discusses Hugging Face's palm-sized robot that runs fully local (no cloud/APIs), with real-time listening, vision, and response capabilities. Emphasizes shift from cloud-dependent to edge AI.
items.content_html:
Most people think ‚ÄúAI in the real world‚Äù means another app.

I think that‚Äôs wrong.

This palm-sized robot from @huggingface runs fully local, no cloud, no APIs, no black box, yet it listens, sees, learns, and responds in real time.

That shift changes everything.

Here‚Äôs why it matters ‚Üí

items.title: n config options can often be replaced by k options (with k << n) where k just lets the user e...
items.content:
n config options can often be replaced by k options (with k << n) where k just lets the user express what thing they want to optimize for (typically some tradeoff between latency, throughput, and cost).

This is often very hard! But a 10x better user experience.

items.content:
Here are some highlights from this past week üö¢: 

‚Äî Personal Intelligence expanded to AI Mode in Google Search, unlocking Search responses uniquely helpful and relevant to you. Personal Intelligence in Search can securely connect to @Gmail and @GooglePhotos. Connecting these apps is available via opt-in to U.S. AI Pro and Ultra subscribers

‚Äî The Gemini app also expanded to 23 new languages, making it available in more than 70 languages and over 230 countries and territories

‚Äî We introduced the @StitchbyGoogle MCP Server, which allows you to pipe Stitch creations into tools like @antigravity so you can generate new screens without leaving your IDE, fetch code from any design, give your agent full visual awareness, and more

‚Äî We‚Äôre launching free, full-length practice exams for standardized tests in @GeminiApp, starting with the SAT practice test that‚Äôs available now

Here are some highlights from this past week üö¢:

‚Äî Personal Intelligence expanded to AI Mode in Google Search, unlocking Search responses uniquely helpful and relevant to you. Personal Intelligence in Search can securely connect to @Gmail and @GooglePhotos. Connecting these apps is available via opt-in to U.S. AI Pro and Ultra subscribers

‚Äî The Gemini app also expanded to 23 new languages, making it available in more than 70 languages and over 230 countries and territories

‚Äî We introduced the @StitchbyGoogle MCP Server, which allows you to pipe Stitch creations into tools like @antigravity so you can generate new screens without leaving your IDE, fetch code from any design, give your agent full visual awareness, and more

‚Äî We‚Äôre launching free, full-length practice exams for standardized tests in @GeminiApp, starting with the SAT practice test that‚Äôs available now

‚Äî Free, full-length practice exams in @GeminiApp to help students prepare for standardized tests. We partnered with @ThePrincetonRev to launch the SAT practice exam first, with more practice tests coming soon

‚Äî @KhanAcademy integrated Gemini capabilities into its new literacy tools. Writing Coach is available now to help students master essays, with Reading Coach launching soon

‚Äî Gemini in https://t.co/daRZlQGQgf, the nonprofit peer-to-peer tutoring platform. Schoolhouse uses Gemini capabilities to inform feedback and coaching for tutors, enabling them to elevate the quality of their tutoring sessions

If you mean selectively deleting the context from your main session after executing, that has prompt caching impacts and not clear its good because Claude generated its output conditioned on the context.

items.title: @BenjaminDEKR No, it's an old model that shouldn't be used anymore. We should get people to use FSD ...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer strongly advocating Tesla FSD over legacy Autopilot, arguing old AI model is unsafe and should be replaced. Suggests lightweight FSD for freeways, warns against over-reliance on inferior systems.
items.reasoning: Substantive opinion on autonomous driving AI safety with specific reasoning about model currency and safety implications. Relevant to AI deployment practices.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer strongly advocating Tesla FSD over legacy Autopilot, arguing old AI model is unsafe and should be replaced. Suggests lightweight FSD for freeways, warns against over-reliance on inferior systems.
items.content_html:
@BenjaminDEKR No, it's an old model that shouldn't be used anymore. We should get people to use FSD instead. FSD is far safer, far superior, far smoother, and far better in all ways.

I wouldn't be shocked if they develop a lightweight version of FSD that, for instance, might work on freeways only. However, when you experience both systems, they're not even close.

It is actually less safe to use an inferior system because you start becoming overly reliant on it, and then it makes a mistake. You need to stay up to date with the latest AI if you're going to have AI driving your car. That is a good question.

items.title:
The bigger idea most people miss:

This isn‚Äôt about robots.
It‚Äôs about embodied AI.

When AI can:

‚Üí...
items.content:
The bigger idea most people miss:

This isn‚Äôt about robots.
It‚Äôs about embodied AI.

When AI can:

‚Üí hear its environment
‚Üí see context
‚Üí move with intent

You stop prompting models.
You start designing behavior.

That‚Äôs a different mental model entirely.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Ronald van Loon on embodied AI concept: when AI can hear, see, and move with intent, 'you stop prompting models. You start designing behavior.' Different mental model for AI development.
items.reasoning: Conceptual framing of paradigm shift in AI interaction. Part of substantive thread on physical AI.

items.title: @CosminDolha Yeah, the question is how to get everyone to switch ecosystems. Dave Winer used to tell...
items.content:
@CosminDolha Yeah, the question is how to get everyone to switch ecosystems. Dave Winer used to tell me "Apple has you locked in the trunk." Now we understand what he meant by that. 

One thing: when paradigm shifts hit we will reevaluate our choices. 

Next paradigm: glasses.
Paradigm after that, which is bigger: brain computer interfaces.

We won't switch our phones easily.

But as we move to glasses we will reevaluate.

items.title:
Nothing in AI is locked in yet. Nothing is solved.

AI is so young and changing so fast that if you ...
items.content:
Nothing in AI is locked in yet. Nothing is solved.

AI is so young and changing so fast that if you go to sleep on Friday, your knowledge will be outdated by Monday.

This is kinda scary, but it's also a huge opportunity to learn and build.

Don't wait for somebody to tell you how to do things; start experimenting for yourself.

Sit down next weekend, install Claude Code on your computer, and start building something‚Äîanything.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago emphasizes AI is changing so fast knowledge becomes outdated weekend-to-weekend, urges experimentation with Claude Code
items.reasoning: Call to action for hands-on AI learning from credible educator. Captures current pace of change sentiment.
items.summary_html: Santiago emphasizes AI is changing so fast knowledge becomes outdated weekend-to-weekend, urges experimentation with Claude Code
items.content_html:
Nothing in AI is locked in yet. Nothing is solved.

AI is so young and changing so fast that if you go to sleep on Friday, your knowledge will be outdated by Monday.

This is kinda scary, but it's also a huge opportunity to learn and build.

Don't wait for somebody to tell you how to do things; start experimenting for yourself.

Sit down next weekend, install Claude Code on your computer, and start building something‚Äîanything.

items.title:
@michejafang This is a great report; I really got a lot out of it. 

I visited the Matic Robot Compa...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer visited Matic Robot Company, observed manufacturing challenges with 50 robots stacked due to glue formulation issues from vendor. Notes manufacturing complexity.
items.reasoning: First-hand insight into robotics manufacturing challenges. Real-world operational perspective.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer visited Matic Robot Company, observed manufacturing challenges with 50 robots stacked due to glue formulation issues from vendor. Notes manufacturing complexity.
items.content_html:
@michejafang This is a great report; I really got a lot out of it.

I visited the Matic Robot Company this week and noticed they had about 50 robots all stacked up on shelves. Robots were everywhere! When I asked what they were for, they explained that they had a manufacturing problem: the vendor that makes the glue on the bags changed the formula, causing it to fail a lot of quality assurance checks. Now, they are remaking the bags.

Manufacturing is brutally tough. This experience gave me a new respect for what goes on inside factories to make these products.

What surprised me most wasn‚Äôt the hardware.

It was the workflow.

‚Üí You code behaviors in Python
‚Üí ...
items.content:
What surprised me most wasn‚Äôt the hardware.

It was the workflow.

‚Üí You code behaviors in Python
‚Üí You test them in simulation
‚Üí You deploy to a physical robot
‚Üí You share and remix behaviors globally

That‚Äôs not a toy pipeline.

That‚Äôs how real AI systems are built.

It was the workflow.

‚Üí You code behaviors in Python

‚Üí You test them in simulation

‚Üí You deploy to a physical robot

‚Üí You share and remix behaviors globally

That‚Äôs not a toy pipeline.

That‚Äôs how real AI systems are built.

items.title: Not for or against this btw but this is Bending Spoons, an Italian P/E firm that acts like a startup...
items.content:
Not for or against this btw but this is Bending Spoons, an Italian P/E firm that acts like a startup

They raise a lot of money to acquire stagnant or failed startups

Then they fire everyone, replace them with cheap labor (costs go down), and increase the prices (revenue goes up) while improving or simplifying the product

They're the ones who acquired Evernote too

"Bending Spoons implement a classic software investment strategy by acquiring an underperforming software business and combining aggressive financial strategies with technological innovation

Many of the companies that Bending Spoons acquires are based in Silicon Valley, which has labor costs that are significantly higher than in Italy, where Bending Spoons is based.

By getting rid of the expensive US employees and moving the team to Italy they are able to reduce expenses and take advantage of their shared services.

They substantially raise subscription prices to maximize revenue from dedicated users. Many customers churn, but the profits increase substantially."
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: levelsio explains Bending Spoons' acquisition strategy - buy struggling startups, cut US staff, raise prices
items.reasoning: Very high engagement (288K views) tech business analysis but not AI-specific

items.title:
@jsof2010 @MrGoldBro Picking winners is difficult, especially if you are investing in the future. 

...
items.content:
@jsof2010 @MrGoldBro Picking winners is difficult, especially if you are investing in the future. 

Who are the investors who back companies that make the future better? 

Instagram, when it got acquired had almost no employees, no sales, no profits, no assets.

I had a roomful of billionaires tell me on the day that it was purchased that it was the worst acquisition they ever heard of. 

Yet today it's worth hundreds of billions of dollars.

I'd rather go with the investor who saw that someday it would be worth hundreds of billions and didn't look at the fundamentals like everyone else.

Which is why contrarians often make the best investors.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer discussing contrarian investing using Instagram acquisition as example - room of billionaires thought it was worst acquisition ever, now worth hundreds of billions
items.reasoning: Interesting investment philosophy discussion relevant to AI startup evaluation but not directly about AI technology

"The weather is warm. I go to the beach."

Is it possible to submit this entire text and obtain two separate audio files: the first one for "The weather is warm." and the second for "I go to the beach."?

items.title:
@Kyrannio Well, clearly a lot of people believe like you do, and I do too.

I think the new algorith...
items.content:
@Kyrannio Well, clearly a lot of people believe like you do, and I do too.

I think the new algorithm has taken some fun out of the service by being too good, actually. All the posts I see are really good posts, but something is missing. That's why I go back to lists; there's more of a community in those.

But there's something else: I think a lot of people aren't replying. There's just not a good back-and-forth, and I think part of that is because there's so much content here.

When I'm watching X-Pro, there's a new tweet every quarter second. There's just too much to read, too much to do, and too much to try. It's wearing on all of us.

And then there's the assholes and the politics that grind you down.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer reflects on X algorithm being 'too good' at surfacing quality content, but something is missing - returns to lists for community feel. Notes overwhelming content volume.
items.reasoning: Platform commentary, not AI-specific despite algorithm mention.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer reflects on X algorithm being 'too good' at surfacing quality content, but something is missing - returns to lists for community feel. Notes overwhelming content volume.
items.content_html:
@Kyrannio Well, clearly a lot of people believe like you do, and I do too.

I think the new algorithm has taken some fun out of the service by being too good, actually. All the posts I see are really good posts, but something is missing. That's why I go back to lists; there's more of a community in those.

But there's something else: I think a lot of people aren't replying. There's just not a good back-and-forth, and I think part of that is because there's so much content here.

When I'm watching X-Pro, there's a new tweet every quarter second. There's just too much to read, too much to do, and too much to try. It's wearing on all of us.

And then there's the assholes and the politics that grind you down.

items.content:
@llgobindram @ProductHunt @jowyang Yeah, there are some disadvantages:

1. You have a little thing hanging off the bottom of your phone, which is easy to lose and get disconnected
2. It's a little slow, so you have to wait for it to work
3. You gotta use it with an app that requires a bit of setup

Other than that, it's really interesting. It does what it says.

Other than that, it's really interesting. It does what it says.

items.title:
‚ùä Added press K for Engine On/Off

So now you can glide back down based on the kinetic energy stored...
items.content:
‚ùä Added press K for Engine On/Off

So now you can glide back down based on the kinetic energy stored in the plane at higher altitudes

Planes in general can glide a lot, even heavy jets like an Airbus A380, as long as they're at high altitude, so they use that altitude energy and convert that into distance, an A380 can glide like 250km to the nearest airport

I do this a lot in Flight Simulator 2024, I take off, kill the engines and see if I can get back to the airport in time before crashing

Planes in general can glide a lot, even heavy jets like an Airbus A380, as long as they're at high altitude, so they use that altitude energy and convert that into distance, an A380 can glide like 250km to the nearest airport

I do this a lot in Flight Simulator 2024, I take off, kill the engines and see if I can get back to the airport in time before crashing

@elonmusk You say it like being an optimist is a choice one can make. It's built-in; sometimes you can have it as a kid, but then life experiences turn you into a pessimist.

You can want very much to become an optimist again, but you cannot make yourself feel this way anymore. Not without taking something special.

This "rule-based order" that all the modern so-called leaders of unclear provenance have been mooing about like cows didn't exist until circa the year 2000.

These shady folks protecting this rule-based order, whose rules have never been published, have interestingly started their careers as top-level politicians approximatively at this same period.

items.title: did you know the majority of cherry trees in japan are clones of a single hybrid from 100+ years ago...
items.content:
did you know the majority of cherry trees in japan are clones of a single hybrid from 100+ years ago?

about 80% of the cherry trees planted across cities and parks in japan are somei-yoshino, a hybrid created from two wild cherry species. it became the dominant variety in the early 1900s, when it was planted everywhere for its clean look and reliable bloom. because this hybrid doesn‚Äôt reproduce true to type from seed (it‚Äôs self-incompatible), growers propagate it almost entirely through grafting and cuttings, producing genetic clones.

as a result, most cherry trees share the same DNA. that genetic uniformity means they respond to temp changes in very similar ways, which is why blossoms sync within a region: sakura season starts in the south and moves north. this progression is so predictable that it is tracked and known every year as the cherry blossom ‚Äúfront‚Äù.

whether early planners fully understood the long-term cultural effects of spreading one dominant variety is unclear, but the impact is obvious.
items.author: @yoheinakajima
items.summary: yoheinakajima shares interesting fact about cloned cherry trees in Japan
items.reasoning: Off-topic but interesting biology/history content, no AI relevance

as a result, most cherry trees share the same DNA. that genetic uniformity means they respond to temp changes in very similar ways, which is why blossoms sync within a region: sakura season starts in the south and moves north. this progression is so predictable that it is tracked and known every year as the cherry blossom ‚Äúfront‚Äù.

items.title: One of the things that I never got used to after all these years of living in the US is how wildly e...
items.content: One of the things that I never got used to after all these years of living in the US is how wildly extreme the climate can be over here, especially anywhere east of the Rockies. Both between the seasons, and between the regions. During the Winter you can literally drive north to south in a single day and go from the arctic hellscape to a tropical paradise. This year the difference is just a bit more extreme, but a version of this happens almost every year.
